Art. 4.64. 
Valuation of usufruct 
Unless the parties have agreed otherwise, the value of the usufruct is calculated on the basis of the market value of the property, the age of the usufructuary on the day on which the request referred to in Article 4.63, ¤ 1, subparagraph 1 is made and the conversion tables referred to in paragraph 3. 
Where the surviving spouse has descendants from a previous relationship, the surviving spouse is deemed to be at least twenty years older than the eldest of the descendants from a previous relationship.
The Minister of Justice establishes two conversion tables for the conversion of usufruct: one for men and the other for women.   
These conversion tables express the value of the usufruct as a percentage of the normal market value of the property subject to the usufruct, taking into account: 
1¡ the average interest rate over the last two years of linear bonds with a maturity equal to the life expectancy of the usufructuary. The interest rate corresponding to the highest maturity applies when the life expectancy is greater than this maturity. This interest rate is applied after deduction of withholding tax. However, the interest rate to be taken into account when establishing the conversion tables may not be less than 1% per annum. The two-year period runs from 1 May of the second year preceding the publication of the conversion tables to 30 April of the year of publication of these tables; 
2¡ the Belgian prospective mortality tables published annually by the Federal Planning Bureau.
However, where, due to the state of health of the usufructuary, his probable life expectancy is manifestly less than that set out in the statistical tables, and if Article 4.61, ¤ 4, paragraph 1 has not been applied, the court may, at the request of a bare owner or the surviving spouse, disregard the conversion tables and set other conversion conditions.
The Minister of Justice establishes, on 1 July of each year, the conversion tables referred to in paragraph 3, subparagraph 1. In doing so, he shall take into account the parameters mentioned in paragraph 1 and paragraph 3, subparagraph 2 and the proposals sent to him by the Royal Federation of Belgian Notaries after having taken note of the results of the work of the Federal Planning Bureau and the Institute of Actuaries in Belgium.
The conversion tables are published each year in the Moniteur belge. These tables indicate, in relation to the age of the usufructuary, his life expectancy as well as the corresponding interest rate and value of the usufruct.
 The value of the usufruct provided by the conversion tables is equal to the difference between the value of the full ownership and the value of the bare ownership. The value of the bare ownership is equal to a fraction, the numerator of which is equal to the value of the full ownership; the denominator is equal to unity, increased by the interest rate, this sum being raised to a power equal to the life expectancy of the usufructuary. Two decimal places are used for life expectancy expressed in years, for the interest rate expressed as a percentage, and for the value of the usufruct expressed as a percentage of the value of the full ownership.
